metadata.synopsis: Raphael offers his deal to free Orpheus - no Voss variant. Voss is either dead or not present currently
metadata.how_to_trigger: Either ingore Voss in Sharess Caress Taproom or use oe RaphaelTango_Reset_VossDead, find Korrilla in SC, talk to her, let her lead you to Raph's room and then enter the room

8.speaker: Narrator
8.text: *A crackle at the edge of your consciousness... the Emperor has been silenced once more.*

90.speaker: Raphael
90.text: Here we are again. Have you reconsidered? Would you like to hear what I'm offering?

211.speaker: Player
211.text: What do you have that I could possibly want?

174.speaker: Raphael
174.text: I'm glad you came. Not to my door, not yet, but to the final reckoning.
174.context: NodeContext: With a smile - genuinely pleased to be coming to the final stage of his business with the players

252.speaker: Raphael
252.text: I trust you'll be on better behaviour than when we last met. There's precious little time remaining for your mischief.

192.speaker: Raphael
192.text: One more thing before we begin, though.

137.context: CinematicNodeContext: Raphael clicks his fingers, and the lights in the room dim for a moment. He smiles.

24.speaker: Narrator
24.text: *For the first time since the nautiloid, your mind is clear. It's... unsettling.*

233.speaker: Player
233.text: Did you just cure me of the tadpole? With a click of your fingers?

12.speaker: Raphael
12.text: Wouldn't that be exquisite? But no.

255.speaker: Raphael
255.text: I'm afraid the tadpole is still there. But I did shut out your other visitor for a while, so we can enjoy some privacy.

190.speaker: Raphael
190.context: NodeContext: pleased with himself - he just did something we thought impossible

223.speaker: Karlach
223.context: NodeContext: Reracting to Raphael stopping the Emperor (illithid tadpole guy) from talking to us. Suspicious but curious/ maybe even a little impressed.

72.speaker: Player
72.text: I'd take a mind flayer over a devil any day.

260.speaker: Player
260.text: I trust the illithid more than I trust you.

140.speaker: Player
140.text: Then speak freely - tell me why you brought me here.

97.speaker: Raphael
97.text: I brought you here because I'm true to my word, and I can make all of this tadpole business go away.

117.speaker: Raphael
117.text: Which means you and your lovely friends can remain blessedly free of tentacles.

197.speaker: Raphael
197.text: Unless some have already sprouted in places I can't see.

118.speaker: Raphael
118.text: I'll admit - you've impressed me. I wasn't sure you'd make it this far.

214.speaker: Raphael
214.text: But no matter how far you come, you're still on the road to ruin - a road that leads directly to a confrontation with the elder brain.
214.context: NodeContext: laying out the facts - he wants us to understand the gravity of the situation

154.speaker: Raphael
154.text: At best, it will kill you and everyone else in this city. At worst, it will assimilate you, and you won't have enough free will left to even wish you were dead.
154.context: NodeContext: laying out the facts - he wants us to understand the gravity of the situation

50.speaker: Raphael
50.text: You have the key to destroying it in the palm of your hand, though.
50.context: NodeContext: open - he's trying to win us over

199.speaker: Raphael
199.text: No, Gale. Mystra might have you believe martyrdom is the only solution. I offer you a way to survive.

248.speaker: Raphael
248.text: In a manner of speaking. But it's the one inside the Prism that you need. Not the illithid - the gith.

144.speaker: Raphael
144.text: No, no, no. It has only helped to push you toward your own destruction. It wants you to be an illithid, the very thing you have sought to avoid.
144.context: NodeContext: slightly irritated - but only slightly.  as if speaking to a stupid child

23.speaker: Raphael
23.text: It is the illithid's prisoner that can save you. The gith.

68.speaker: Raphael
68.text: I can give you the means to break him free.
68.context: NodeContext: making a grand offer - this is big news delivered solemnly

224.speaker: Raphael
224.text: The Orphic Hammer. An artefact capable of shattering the chains that hold Prince Orpheus is held securely in my House of Hope even now.

88.speaker: Player
88.text: Then you will hand it over. Orpheus must be set free.

45.speaker: Raphael
45.text: Surely you realise, there is an exchange to be made. You scratch my back, I scratch your parasite.
45.context: NodeContext: second 'scratch' as in erase. A ltitle bit of wordplay

253.speaker: Karlach
253.context: NodeContext: Raphael's proposing a 'trade', so Karlach is like... of course he is.

196.speaker: Player
196.text: Wouldn't expect more. So what do you want?

168.speaker: Player
168.text: What are you hoping to get out of all this?

221.speaker: Raphael
221.text: Power. You free Orpheus, and in doing so, save the city, the Sword Coast, perhaps the whole world... and your own precious skin, too.
221.context: NodeContext: He's speaking to us almost as equals here. Being very honest about what he wants - 'power'. No more lies. Just the plain facts.

111.speaker: Raphael
111.text: And you give me the Crown that dominates the elder brain.
111.context: NodeContext: this is the crux of his offer - he says it with the boldness of somebody used to getting what he wants.

237.speaker: Player
237.text: I suppose you want my soul in exchange for the Hammer?

92.speaker: Raphael
92.text: You really do think highly of yourself. My sights are set on something much more valuable than your soul, succulent though it would be.

26.speaker: Raphael
26.text: I want the Crown that dominates the elder brain.
26.context: NodeContext: this is the crux of his offer - he says it with the boldness of somebody used to getting what he wants.

251.speaker: Raphael
251.text: And you, Lae'zel of K'liir, want to free the forgotten prince, do you not?

131.speaker: Lae'zel
131.text: I don't want to free him. I want to kill him.

14.speaker: Raphael
14.text: Lae'zel of K'liir - do you think you can take a blade to the prince while the illithid still binds him?

220.speaker: Raphael
220.text: Goodness, no. If you wish Gith's long-suffering son dead, you need the Hammer.

186.speaker: Raphael
186.text: Then it is settled, is it not? A Crown for a Hammer. A bargain of a lifetime, Lae'zel of K'liir.

155.speaker: Gale
155.text: The Crown of Karsus cannot be handed over to this devil.  Agree to nothing.

55.speaker: Gale
55.text: Handing that crown to this devil would be like feeding gunpowder to a lava worm. Agree to nothing.

230.speaker: Narrator
230.text: *This is your chance to free Gith's only son - but Raphael might wreak untold havok with this Crown.*

122.speaker: Narrator
122.text: *But perhaps there is another way to take the Hammer, a way into the seat of Raphael's operations - the House of Hope.*

61.speaker: Player
61.text: I'm tempted - but tell me why you're so eager to get hold of the crown?

182.speaker: Raphael
182.text: Power. Ancient and full of wonder.

84.speaker: Raphael
84.text: I have craved it ever since the archwizard Karsus created it, long centuries ago, and brought doom to the empire of Netheril.
84.context: NodeContext: reminiscing about a formative and awesome moment from his past - moving into storytelling mode as he begins a monologue that continues for several lines

67.speaker: Raphael
67.text: That was the great age of humanity, and Netheril's flying sky-cities were the apex of civilisation.

70.speaker: Raphael
70.text: I was there the day it all fell apart. Entire cities plummeted from the sky, like angels with broken wings.
70.context: NodeContext: reminiscing about a formative and awesome moment from his past

19.speaker: Raphael
19.text: The screams, oh the screams - hundreds of thousands of people watching in horror as the ground came up to meet them. It was not a happy meeting.
19.context: NodeContext: reminiscing about a formative and awesome moment from his past - last phrase with a smile. He finds this funny.

242.speaker: Raphael
242.text: And Karsus was responsible. Not driven by malice, but by ambition. He forged a Crown imbued with all the powers of magic, a Crown that would make any who wore it a god.

82.speaker: Raphael
82.text: Men cannot contain so much power. The Crown destroyed its creator, and his empire fell with him.

47.speaker: Narrator
47.text: *Could this be the crown worn by the elder brain? The word of a devil counts for little, but perhaps you might find more reliable proof on the arcane bookshelves of Sorcerous Sundries...*

77.speaker: Raphael
77.text: Karsus' Folly, the bards and scholars call it. I call it hope. The hope of creating a better world, and the perils of unchecked hubris.
77.context: NodeContext: reminiscing about a formative and awesome moment from his past

79.speaker: Raphael
79.text: I knew then that the folly of mortals could be the triumph of devils, and that I could use that Crown to unite the Nine under one Archdevil Supreme. Me.
79.context: NodeContext: reminiscing about a formative and awesome moment from his past - builds to a self-satisfied and slightly sinister note as he finishes

241.speaker: Karlach
241.text: Zariel wouldn't like that much. But even I'm not so desperate to spite her I'd put the Hells in this bastard's hands.
241.context: NodeContext: She's in the party when Raphael says he wants the Crown of Karsus so he can unite and rule the Hells. She's amused at the idea of spiting Zariel, but still not willing to help Raphael

27.speaker: Player
27.text: I'm sure all you devils will play nice once you have a new tyrant.

193.speaker: Raphael
193.text: The Hells require order to function. It is what separates us from mortals and demons.

184.speaker: Player
184.text: The idea of you ruling all Nine Hells doesn't fill me with joy.

205.speaker: Player
205.text: You think I'd ever let that happen?

5.speaker: Player
5.text: I think you'd make a fantastic Archdevil Supreme.

16.speaker: Raphael
16.text: You're too kind. And extremely insightful.
16.context: NodeContext: with a light mocking bow

18.speaker: Raphael
18.text: With the Crown, I would impose perfect order. Unity. Efficiency. Control. My kingdom would control its borders, and stay within them.

148.speaker: Player
148.text: Why haven't you got hold of the Crown already?

98.speaker: Raphael
98.text: It was stolen from right under my nose, all those centuries ago.

38.speaker: Player
38.text: What makes you think you'd succeed in using the Crown where Karsus couldn't?

7.speaker: Raphael
7.context: NodeContext: a sudden flare of rage

244.speaker: Raphael
244.context: NodeContext: regaining his composure after shouting the previous line

42.speaker: Player
42.text: If you don't fail, how come you didn't get hold of the Crown way back when?

139.speaker: Player
139.text: What's your plan? Beat up all the other devils?

29.speaker: Player
29.text: Why didn't you take the Crown there and then?

259.speaker: Raphael
259.text: The archdevil Mephistopheles snatched up the Crown and squirrelled it away in one of his vaults. He's naught more than a frigid archivist.
259.context: NodeContext: annoyance with Mephistopheles through this next monologue - reminiscing again

17.speaker: Raphael
17.text: So much power and potential kept inert. He made a miracle into a museum piece.
17.context: NodeContext: annoyance with Mephistopheles through this next monologue - reminiscing again

188.speaker: Raphael
188.text: I raged - but only for a decade or so - then I waited, ever-watching, for more than a thousand years, for a mistake, a mishap, a misadventure.
188.context: NodeContext: he's being droll about raging for a decade

41.speaker: Raphael
41.text: And these Chosen who have caused you so much trouble accidentally did me a favour.
41.context: NodeContext: emphasis on Chosen is emphasising his contempt for them - they're beneath him

21.speaker: Raphael
21.text: They brought the Crown back into play.

35.speaker: Player
35.text: It must really annoy you that some mortals managed to steal the Crown when you couldn't.

200.speaker: Raphael
200.text: Yes. It does. Especially when I see what a bloody mess they've made of their whole scheme.
200.context: NodeContext: Annoyed - but tight-lipped and keeping his fury under control

245.speaker: Player
245.text: How did they come to have the Crown?

142.speaker: Raphael
142.text: Through the aid of a diabolist, somebody capable of opening a portal to the Hells. Deep in the Hells.

96.speaker: Raphael
96.text: They must have raided Mephistopheles' vault. Impressive, I must admit.
96.context: NodeContext: begrudging admiration for people he thinks of as being beneath him

222.speaker: Raphael
222.text: If you don't kill them, the elder brain will. It doesn't have feelings in the way you'd understand them - but it seems rather angry.
222.context: NodeContext: amused by his final statement

208.speaker: Raphael
208.text: It is inevitable. When you destroy the brain - and you will, because you must - the Crown will be yours for the taking.

123.speaker: Raphael
123.text: And when that moment comes, you give the Crown to me. In exchange, I give you the Hammer now.

54.speaker: Narrator
54.text: *A simple transaction, it seems, but it's more than that - he's offering you an alternative to the mind flayer in your head.*

30.speaker: Narrator
30.text: *Take Raphael's deal, and you could break Orpheus from his prison and bleed him dry. But what would become of your protection from the Absolute?*

189.speaker: Narrator
189.text: *And if you take the deal, you'll have to fulfil it. You'll have to deliver the Crown of Karsus to the Devil himself.*

31.speaker: Narrator
31.text: *He claims his ambition is to unite the Hells. But can he be trusted to stop there? Do you trust him more than you trust the Emperor?*

249.speaker: Lae'zel
249.text: Tsk'va. We should do as the devil asks. The Prince of the Comet must rise again.

195.speaker: Lae'zel
195.text: Tsk'va. We should do as the devil asks. I cannot slay Orpheus if I cannot break him free.

109.speaker: Player
109.text: The Prince of the Comet must rise again. I accept your bargain.

37.speaker: Player
37.text: I can't believe I'm doing this again, but I accept your deal, fiend.

2.context: NodeContext: Player offers to sign a deal with Raphael.

172.speaker: Raphael
172.context:
CinematicNodeContext: he gestures to a contract on the table
[MK] - This has now been update to a floating contract for ease of authoring and animation

165.speaker: Raphael
165.text: You'll find everything is in order.

239.speaker: Raphael
239.text: The moment I have your signature, you will have the means to free Orpheus - the Hammer.

11.speaker: Raphael
11.text: You guarantee the Crown will be mine once the brain is defeated. And I swear that I will never use the Crown to dominate a mortal.

166.speaker: Raphael
166.text: Perfect. One more rhyme, for old times' sake.
166.context: CinematicNodeContext: [MK] - Player takes and signs the contract before line is delivered - Anim re-use

115.speaker: Raphael
115.text: The master was slain within his own house.
115.context: NodeContext: reciting the end of a poem

114.speaker: Raphael
114.text: They dined on him both, the cat and the mouse.
114.context: NodeContext: reciting the end of a poem

57.speaker: Raphael
57.text: The Hammer is yours. You will find yourself in Orpheus' presence before the end comes - when you do, shatter the chains that hold him.

194.speaker: Raphael
194.text: Be sure to keep the Hammer safe until then. Your survival depends on it.

120.speaker: Raphael
120.text: And I'll keep your contract safe, in my House of Hope.

112.speaker: Raphael
112.text: And our deal depends on your contract. I'll keep it safe for you, in my House of Hope.

36.speaker: Raphael
36.text: For my part, I'll keep your contract safe and secure in my house.

66.speaker: Raphael
66.text: I'll be seeing you. And when I do - we dine.
66.context: NodeContext: With a smile - we just made a deal with him, and he's very pleased

children.speaker: Gale
children.text: Wherever this 'House of Hope' is, we need to go there immediately and destroy that contract. We must speak with Helsik. Only a diabolist will know the way.
children.context: NodeContext: Urgent, not waiting for a reply
children.speaker: Gale
children.text: Wherever this 'House of Hope' is, we need to go there immediately and destroy that contract. We must speak with Helsik - she's the only one who can show us the way.
children.speaker: Gale
children.text: Wherever this 'House of Hope' is, we need to go there immediately and destroy that contract. We must speak with Korrilla. If anyone knows the way, it will be her.
children.speaker: Gale
children.text: Wherever this 'House of Hope' is, we need to go there immediately and destroy that contract. We must find a diabolist. Only one well-versed in devilry will know the way.
children.speaker: Narrator
children.text: *The ink has barely dried, yet you feel a growing disquiet at what exactly you just signed. Perhaps a diabolist can offer some comfort. Or a way out... for a devil's bargain is a hard one to break.*

147.speaker: Player
147.text: What happens if I don't give you the Crown when the time comes?

103.speaker: Raphael
103.text: I will come to collect. If you refuse to give me the Crown, I collect your souls instead.
103.context: NodeContext: a simple declaration of fact - not a threat

201.speaker: Raphael
201.text: And then we all gather in the House of Hope - me dressed in my finest silks, you, skinless, hanging from a hook - to watch as your world dies.
201.context: NodeContext: relishing how uncomfortable and afraid he's making us

215.speaker: Player
215.text: I will find another way. Your bargain is worthless.

257.speaker: Raphael
257.text: I won't stop you. But time is running out, so don't stay away for long.

39.speaker: Raphael
39.text: If you see reason, I'll be here, waiting, right up to the moment the world ends.
39.context: NodeContext: He's got all the time in the world - nonchalant, despite the gravity of the statement

176.speaker: Player
176.text: I agree to the deal. Where do I sign?

91.speaker: Player
91.text: I'd rather destroy the Crown than risk it falling into the wrong hands again.

15.speaker: Raphael
15.text: How short-sighted. Much better to put it into the right hands - hands that will ensure it is removed from this world.

80.speaker: Raphael
80.text: And it's the only way you can ensure that you remain part of this world.

107.speaker: Player
107.text: You were very amenable helping with Cazador. We do well, working together.

100.speaker: Player
100.text: I'd rather eat the Crown and shit it out than see it on your head.

46.speaker: Player
46.text: I'll control the Crown myself once I have the Netherstones.

167.speaker: Raphael
167.text: Ha. Ha ha ha. Ha ha ha ha ha.
167.context: CinematicNodeContext: laughter builds - he finds your comment ridiculousNodeContext: laughter builds - he finds your comment ridiculous

138.speaker: Raphael
138.text: Oh - I'm sorry. You were serious? The Crown has laid low all who attempt to harness its power - archwizards, emperors, gods.
138.context: NodeContext: after laughing at us - still very amused, but also incredulous

34.speaker: Player
34.text: A worthless bargain. I will find my own way.

164.speaker: Narrator
164.text: *You could free Orpheus, the future of the Githyanki Empire, if you take Raphael's deal. And with Orpheus free, you would have no need to rely on the Emperor.*

0.speaker: Narrator
0.text: *Take Raphael's deal, and you could free Orpheus. With Orpheus free, you would have no need to rely on the Emperor.*

235.speaker: Narrator
235.text: *But there's no guarantee that Orpheus would be on your side.*

133.speaker: Player
133.text: What makes you so sure I'll get the Crown?

152.speaker: Player
152.text: I'll take the Crown and use its power myself.

94.speaker: Narrator
94.text: *The Crown of Karsus? The word of a devil counts for little, but in the written word you may yet find proof. Your trip to Sorcerous Sundries is more urgent than ever.*

78.speaker: Player
78.text: I'd be insane to give such a powerful artefact to a devil.

225.speaker: Raphael
225.text: Better to have it in my hands - and far from your precious world - than in the hands of the gods and monsters that fight over this city's soul.
225.context: NodeContext: bargaining mode - he's negotiating now. Rising intensity

163.speaker: Raphael
163.text: Then you will die, along with every other soul in this city.

151.speaker: Player
151.text: Maybe I'll reconsider - but why are you so eager to get your claws on the crown?

175.speaker: Player
175.text: I will save every soul in the city, with a clear heart.

69.speaker: Player
69.text: I'm going to prove you wrong, devil.

73.speaker: Raphael
73.context: NodeContext: Smiling - he really will enjoy this.

136.speaker: Player
136.text: I'm willing to take the risk and put my faith in the company I keep.

127.speaker: Player
127.text: I will find another way. Your bargain is worthless.

209.speaker: Raphael
209.text: You'll turn on each other before this is done. Mark my words.
209.context: NodeContext: amused by the thought of the players killing one another

93.speaker: Player
93.text: I'm a devil now, because a devil played me for a fool. You will not sway me.

159.speaker: Player
159.text: Just tell me what you want.

256.speaker: Player
256.text: I'm not bargaining with you, Raphael.

76.speaker: Player
76.text: No more contracts. Mizora brought me enough trouble.

219.speaker: Raphael
219.text: I'm not asking you to bargain. I'm asking you to save your soul.

203.speaker: Player
203.text: I'll be taking that. Right now.

9.speaker: Player
9.text: Sounds too good to be true.

183.speaker: Raphael
183.text: Good and truth rarely go hand in hand, but in this case, they are happy bedfellows. And we can be, too.

13.speaker: Raphael
13.text: I swear to you - I have the solution to your problem.

125.speaker: Player
125.text: It's very convenient that you have exactly what I need.

74.speaker: Raphael
74.text: Isn't it just? And it's even more convenient that you can give me exactly what I want in return.

213.speaker: Player
213.text: Orpheus' guards tried to kill me - he's dangerous.

229.speaker: Raphael
229.text: To illithids, yes. But despite your reckless embrace of the parasite and recent mutations, you're no mind flayer. Not yet.

218.speaker: Raphael
218.text: Orpheus would gladly execute the Emperor.

171.speaker: Raphael
171.text: To illithids, yes. He would gladly execute the Emperor.

240.speaker: Raphael
240.text: But to you, he will be a friend. After all, you're at war with an elder brain.

236.speaker: Player
236.text: All the evidence I've seen suggests Orpheus is my enemy, and the Emperor my ally.

104.speaker: Player
104.text: The Emperor is the only reason I'm still alive.

63.speaker: Raphael
63.text: No - Orpheus is the only reason you're still alive. The Emperor is abusing the gith for its own ends.
63.context: NodeContext: trying to make a child understand something simple that they simply cannot grasp

173.speaker: Raphael
173.text: And it's doing the same to you. You're nothing more than the beast of burden that will transport it to the elder brain.
173.context: NodeContext: trying to make a child understand something simple that they simply cannot grasp

75.speaker: Player
75.text: Fine - how do I free him?

71.speaker: Player
71.text: I don't want any part of this - the Emperor is my lover.

49.speaker: Raphael
49.text: I have seen all the torments of the Hells in lurid detail - none compare to the image you just conjured.
49.context: NodeContext: the 'image' is a person having sex with a mindflayer. He finds it disgusting

212.speaker: Raphael
212.text: If I'd realised you were so gullible, I'd have tricked you into selling your soul for a pocketful of beans when we first met.

150.speaker: Raphael
150.text: To the Emperor, you are nothing more than a beast of burden - one that will transport it to the elder brain.

216.speaker: Raphael
216.text: An ox requires food and the occasional beating to keep it moving. You are simpler - the Emperor's words serve as both carrot and stick.
216.context: NodeContext: trying to make a child understand something simple that they simply cannot grasp

169.speaker: Narrator
169.text: *Perhaps it is true that Orpheus would ally with you against the elder brain, but if he proves uncooperative once free, you may have to kill him.*

149.speaker: Player
149.text: It's worth taking the risk. How do I free Orpheus?

177.speaker: Player
177.text: I'm convinced. Tell me how to free Orpheus.

105.speaker: Player
105.text: Why would I want to free him?

6.speaker: Raphael
6.text: I suppose you'd rather suck on the Emperor's tentacles 'til the end of your days?
6.context: NodeContext: disgusted and amused by the player

129.speaker: Raphael
129.text: Orpheus is your only hope of surviving this horror show without devolving into an illithid.

56.speaker: Raphael
56.text: To you, he will be a friend. After all, you're at war with an elder brain.

170.speaker: Player
170.text: Clever. But when we first met, you promised me a cure - this isn't a cure.

20.speaker: Raphael
20.text: I'd ask you to be patient, but you've been patient enough. Now is the time to speak plain.

58.speaker: Player
58.text: I'm not scared of that creature. Not when Bhaal himself has hooked his eyes on me.

134.speaker: Raphael
134.text: Oh, come. It's the reason you're in this predicament. And I'm your only way out of it. Indulge me, and at least hear me out.

116.speaker: Player
116.text: I feel... empty. What did you do?

43.speaker: Player
43.text: The tadpole is slumbering... and my blood isn't boiling.

146.speaker: Raphael
146.text: I gave you back your privacy by shutting that illithid in your pocket out of your mind. It can't hear us.
146.context: NodeContext: pleased - he just did something we thought was impossible

22.speaker: Player
22.text: Another party trick. Show me something real.

198.speaker: Raphael
198.text: That was no party trick. Somebody's missing - can't you tell? That illithid you keep in your pocket can't hear us anymore.
198.context: NodeContext: maintaining an air of mystery until the final phrase - like a stage magician revealing that his 'trick' is real magic

178.speaker: Raphael
178.text: Charming as you are, you're a little too empty-headed for my tastes. Send your companion to see me - the one with the passenger in their skull.

162.speaker: Raphael
162.text: And you, Lae'zel of K'liir, want to free the forgotten prince, do you not? Or, perhaps - to kill him?
162.context: InternalNodeContext: Speaking to Lae'zel in slot 2NodeContext: keh-LEAR, Lae'zel's home creche

87.speaker: Raphael
87.text: Whichever way the wind blows you, you'll need the Orphic Hammer in hand.
87.context: InternalNodeContext: Speaking to Lae'zel in slot 2

101.speaker: Raphael
101.text: After all - you can't take a blade to the prince while the illithid still binds him.
